<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 278, 170, 293]]<|/det|>
## PHYSICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 298, 330, 313]]<|/det|>
Paper 6 Alternative to Practical  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[782, 278, 904, 333]]<|/det|>
0625/62May/June 20181 hour  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 339, 415, 374]]<|/det|>
Candidates answer on the Question Paper. No Additional Materials are required.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[93, 390, 386, 406]]<|/det|>
## READ THESE INSTRUCTIONS FIRST  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 416, 718, 490]]<|/det|>
Write your Centre number, candidate number and name on all the work you hand in. Write in dark blue or black pen. You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs. Do not use staples, paper clips, glue or correction fluid. DO NOT WRITE IN ANY BARCODES.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 501, 768, 546]]<|/det|>
Answer all questions. Electronic calculators may be used. You may lose marks if you do not show your working or if you do not use appropriate units.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 556, 758, 586]]<|/det|>
At the end of the examination, fasten all your work securely together. The number of marks is given in brackets [ ] at the end of each question or part question.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 73, 95, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 72, 918, 90]]<|/det|>
A student is determining the density of water. She is provided with a plastic cup, shown in Fig. 1.1.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[460, 102, 536, 173]]<|/det|>
<center>Fig. 1.1</center>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 224, 146, 242]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 223, 751, 241]]<|/det|>
She draws around the base of the cup. Her drawing is shown in Fig. 1.2.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[375, 252, 618, 424]]<|/det|>
<center>Fig. 1.2</center>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 473, 180, 491]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 473, 918, 505]]<|/det|>
From Fig. 1.2, take and record measurements to determine an accurate value for the diameter \(D_{\mathrm{B}}\) of the base of the cup.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[547, 583, 918, 600]]<|/det|>
<form>D_B = ............................................................ cm [2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 615, 181, 632]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 615, 835, 632]]<|/det|>
The student places the cup upside down and draws around the rim of the cup.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 632, 635, 648]]<|/det|>
She determines the diameter \(D_{\mathrm{T}}\) of the rim of the cup.

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[549, 672, 917, 695]]<|/det|>
\[D_{\mathrm{T}} = \text{....................................................} 7.2 \text{ cm}\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 704, 830, 725]]<|/det|>
Calculate the average diameter \(D\) of the cup using the equation \(D = \frac{D_{\mathrm{B}} + D_{\mathrm{T}}}{2}\) .

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[556, 784, 918, 801]]<|/det|>
<form>D = .................................................................... cm [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 73, 148, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 73, 630, 90]]<|/det|>
1. On Fig. 1.3, measure the vertical height \(h\) of the cup.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[316, 101, 775, 377]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[464, 392, 534, 410]]<|/det|>
<pre>Fig. 1.3

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[559, 424, 918, 441]]<|/det|>
<form>h = ........................................................................... $cm$

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 454, 178, 473]]<|/det|>
<label>2.</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 454, 765, 472]]<|/det|>
Calculate the volume \(V\) of the cup using the equation \(V =\) 0.785 \(D^2 h.\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[559, 516, 918, 533]]<|/det|>
<form>V = ........................................................................... $cm^3$

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 533, 920, 549]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 564, 146, 581]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 564, 908, 581]]<|/det|>
The student fills the cup with water. The mass of the cup with the water is shown in Fig. 1.4.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[381, 592, 615, 725]]<|/det|>
<center>Fig. 1.4</center>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 774, 853, 795]]<|/det|>
Determine the density \(\rho\) of water using the equation \(\rho = \frac{m}{V}\) and your value from (b)2.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 806, 918, 840]]<|/det|>
Give your answer to a suitable number of significant figures for this experiment. Include the unit.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[559, 870, 918, 886]]<|/det|>
<form>ρ = ........................................................................... [3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 73, 148, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>(d)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 73, 917, 106]]<|/det|>
Suggest, with a reason, a part of the procedure **(a)**, **(b)** or **(c)** that could give an unreliable result for the density of water.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 120, 320, 136]]<|/det|>
part ........................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 151, 915, 166]]<|/det|>
reason ....................................................................................................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 196, 918, 214]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 228, 146, 246]]<|/det|>
<label>(e)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 228, 712, 244]]<|/det|>
The student pours the water from the cup into a measuring cylinder.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 259, 918, 289]]<|/det|>
Draw a diagram to show water in a measuring cylinder. Show clearly the meniscus and the line of sight the student should use to obtain an accurate value for the volume of the water.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 412, 917, 446]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 603, 148, 621]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 603, 613, 620]]<|/det|>
The student pours \(200 \text{cm}^3\) of hot water into the beaker.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 634, 918, 667]]<|/det|>
He records the temperature \(\theta_{\mathrm{H}}\) of the hot water at time \(t = 0\) and immediately starts a stopclock.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 681, 918, 713]]<|/det|>
He continues recording the temperature readings every 30s. The readings are shown in Table 2.1.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 728, 180, 746]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 728, 918, 760]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[850, 804, 918, 821]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 293, 918, 325]]<|/det|>
The student adjusts the position of the screen until a clearly focused image is formed on the screen.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[560, 462, 918, 479]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 494, 918, 526]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 536, 785, 564]]<|/det|>
Calculate the focal length \(f_{1}\) of the lens using the equation \(f_{1} = \frac{UV}{(U + V)}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[556, 602, 918, 619]]<|/det|>
<form>f_{1} = .................................................................... [2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 632, 148, 650]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[556, 675, 787, 694]]<|/det|>
<form>f_{2} = .................................................... 12.2 cm

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 710, 918, 743]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[78, 73, 92, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>4</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 73, 917, 106]]<|/det|>
A student is investigating whether the distance that a toy truck will travel along a horizontal floor, before stopping, depends on its mass.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 120, 537, 136]]<|/det|>
The following apparatus is available to the student:

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 152, 218, 166]]<|/det|>
a ramp

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 167, 546, 183]]<|/det|>
blocks to support the ramp as shown in Fig. 4.1

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 183, 235, 197]]<|/det|>
toy truck

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 198, 339, 212]]<|/det|>
a selection of masses

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 213, 598, 228]]<|/det|>
other standard apparatus from the physics laboratory.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 243, 918, 275]]<|/det|>
<pre>Plan an experiment to investigate whether the distance that the toy truck will travel along a horizontal floor, before stopping, depends on its mass.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 290, 324, 305]]<|/det|>
<pre>In your plan, you should:

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 320, 655, 337]]<|/det|>
<pre>• explain briefly how you would carry out the investigation

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 352, 812, 368]]<|/det|>
<pre>• state any apparatus that you would use that is not included in the list above

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 383, 568, 399]]<|/det|>
<pre>• state the key variables that you would control

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 414, 918, 446]]<|/det|>
<pre>• draw a table, or tables, with column headings to show how you would display your readings (you are **not** required to enter any readings in the table).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 460, 640, 476]]<|/det|>
<pre>You may add to the diagram in Fig. 4.1 to help your description.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 560, 875, 655]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[465, 744, 532, 759]]<|/det|>
<pre><center>Fig. 4.1</center>
